questions.text: Peripheral blood smear of a patient is given below. The given finding is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The peripheral blood smear shows bite cells which is classically seen in glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.

  • Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) is a crucial enzyme involved in redox metabolism, especially in red blood cells where it generates NADPH.
  • This NADPH protects cells against oxidative stress through the glutathione pathway. In G6PD deficiency, hemolysis is typically triggered by external oxidative agents
  • Although G6PD levels are reduced in other tissues, the clinical impact is primarily seen in red blood cells due to their high oxidative vulnerability.
  • G6PD deficiency is X-linked, making males (who are hemizygous) more susceptible, while females can be homozygous, heterozygous, or mosaics due to X-chromosome inactivation.
  • Some mutations confer protection against Plasmodium falciparum malaria, explaining the high prevalence of the deficiency in tropical regions like Africa, the Middle East, and parts of Europe.
  • Many individuals with G6PD deficiency remain asymptomatic, but they may develop neonatal jaundice or acute hemolytic anemia (AHA) when exposed to oxidative stressors like certain drugs such as dapsone, sulfa drugs, and primaquine. infections and fava beans (favism) are other triggers.
  • Symptoms of AHA can include pallor, jaundice, dark urine, and fatigue.
  • During hemolytic episodes, the peripheral smear shows polychromasia, anisocytosis, and the presence of "bite cells" or "blister cells" which are red cells that appear as if parts of it have been chewed away.
  • Heinz bodies, which are aggregates of denatured hemoglobin, can be visualized with supravital stains like methyl violet.
  • Spherocytes and fragmented red cells may also be seen, reflecting oxidative damage.
  • Preventive strategies include avoiding known oxidative triggers in susceptible individuals.

Explanation of other options:

Sickle cell anemia (Option B): The peripheral smear dense, elongated, and pointed red cells (sickle cells), which are characteristic of sickle cell anemia.

Thalassemia (Option C): In milder forms such as β-thalassemia trait or minor, the blood smear reveals microcytic and hypochromic erythrocytes. In more severe variants like β-thalassemia intermedia, the smear displays prominent features such as hypochromia, microcytosis, marked anisocytosis and poikilocytosis. Target cells are also commonly seen.

questions.text:
Myelophthisis is due to
I. Marrow replaced by fibrous tissue by granulomatous process
II. Marrow replaced by fibrous tissue by primary hematological process
III. Marrow replaced by fibrous tissue by secondary to tumour
questions.solution:
Explanation:

When the bone marrow is replaced by fibrous tissue secondary to granulomatous process or tumour it is called myelophthisis.

  • When the bone marrow cavity is replaced by fibrous tissue made up of reticulin fibers and collagen, it can be classified as either myelofibrosis or myelophthisis depending on the cause.
  • If the fibrosis results from a primary hematologic disorder, it is termed myelofibrosis.
  • On the other hand, when fibrosis is a consequence of external factors like tumors or granulomatous disease infiltrating the marrow, it is referred to as myelophthisis.
  • Myelophthisis or fibrosis may be suspected when bone marrow aspiration yields little or no material which is commonly referred to as a "dry tap."

The image given below shows bone marrow replaced by fibrous tissue.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes rituximab?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rituximab is an anti-CD20 antibody.

  • Rituximab is a monoclonal antibody targeting the CD20 antigen on B-cells. It acts primarily through complement-dependent cytotoxicity and antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity, leading to B-cell depletion. (Option A ruled out)
  • This effect begins within three weeks of therapy and can last 6 to 9 months. B-cell counts usually return to normal by 12 months.
  • The drug is administered intravenously either alone or in combination with chemotherapy.
  • To minimize infusion reactions, premedication with antihistamines, acetaminophen, and steroids is recommended.
  • Rituximab is approved for relapsed indolent lymphomas and is effective in combination with chemotherapy for diffuse large B-cell lymphoma and other B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphomas like CLL, mantle cell lymphoma, and Waldenström macroglobulinemia.
  • Its indications have expanded to several autoimmune disorders such as rheumatoid arthritis, autoimmune hemolytic anemia, and cryoglobulinemia-associated renal disease.
  • Resistance may occur due to loss or mutation of CD20, impaired complement function, or Fc receptor polymorphisms. Infusion-related reactions are usually mild (fever, urticaria, hypotension), but rarely can include severe mucocutaneous reactions like Stevens-Johnson syndrome.
  • Rituximab may reactivate hepatitis B or JC virus and is linked to delayed autoimmune cytopenias (e.g., ITP, autoimmune hemolytic anemia, pure red cell aplasia) that may emerge 1-5 months post-treatment.

Explanations of other options:

Inhibitor of PD-1 (Option C): An example of PD-1 inhibitor (immune checkpoint inhibitor) is nivolumab.

Anti CD52 monoclonal antibody (Option D): An example is alemtuzumab which is used in B-cell CLL

choices.text: Side effects include thrombocytopenia and peripheral neuropathy

questions.text: All are correct about bortezomib except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bortezomib is a proteasome inhibitor, used in multiple myeloma and mantle cell lymphoma.

  • Bortezomib is a first-generation proteasome inhibitor that blocks the β5 subunit of the 20S core of the 26S proteasome, thereby inhibiting chymotrypsin-like activity and inducing apoptosis through disruption of signaling pathways.
  • One of its main effects is blocking NF-κB activation by preventing degradation of IκB (inhibitor of NF-κB), thereby inhibiting survival signals in tumor cells.
  • It also affects cell cycle regulators and promotes apoptosis by disturbing the protein degradation process and inducing unfolded protein response.
  • The drug is administered intravenously on specific days of a 21-day cycle, with a necessary 72-hour gap between doses. It has a plasma half-life of 5.5 hours and a terminal half-life of approximately 24 hours. It is metabolized primarily by CYP3A4, and no dose modification is needed for renal impairment.
  • Therapeutically, Bortezomib is used in initial and relapsed settings for multiple myeloma (MM) and mantle cell lymphoma (MCL). (Options C and D ruled out)
  • It is especially effective when combined with agents like thalidomide or dexamethasone, achieving high response rates in relapsed/refractory myeloma.
  • Adverse effects include thrombocytopenia, fatigue, peripheral neuropathy (especially in those with prior neurotoxic exposure), gastrointestinal symptoms, and hypotension. (Option A ruled out)
  • Peripheral neuropathy may be chronic and more frequent in diabetic or thalidomide-treated patients. Discontinuation or dose reduction can help alleviate symptoms.

questions.text: Transferrin saturation is calculated by?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Transferrin saturation is obtained by formula: Transferrin saturation = (Serum iron × 100) ÷ TIBC, where TIBC is total iron binding capacity.

Iron-deficiency states are associated with saturation levels <20%.

  • Key lab tests for assessing iron availability for hemoglobin production include serum iron, total iron-binding capacity (TIBC), transferrin saturation, and serum ferritin.
  • Transferrin is a glycoprotein composed of two lobes, each capable of binding one iron atom. When it is loaded with iron, it can exist as either a monoferric form, carrying a single iron atom, or a diferric form, carrying two iron atoms.
  • Transferrin saturation is calculated by dividing serum iron (×100) by TIBC. Normal serum iron levels range from 9-27 µmol/L (50-150 µg/dL), and TIBC typically falls between 54-64 µmol/L (300-360 µg/dL), giving a normal transferrin saturation range of 25-50%. This saturation can vary diurnally.
  • Serum ferritin is a marker of total body iron stores. In adult males, levels around 100 µg/L reflect iron reserves of about 1 g, while premenopausal females typically have lower levels corresponding to ~300 mg of stored iron. Levels between 10 - 15 µg/L indicate iron depletion.
  • Ferritin, being an acute-phase reactant, can rise with inflammation or infection, sometimes exceeding 200 µg/L, which generally suggests adequate or elevated iron stores despite potential functional iron deficiency.

questions.text: For maximal absorption, oral iron preparations should be taken?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

For maximal oral absorption oral iron preparations should be taken on an empty stomach.

  • In patients with confirmed iron deficiency anemia and a functioning gastrointestinal tract, oral iron therapy is typically effective.
  • Emphasis is placed on increasing consumption of iron-rich foods like oysters, legumes, meats (especially liver and lean cuts), whole grains, and fortified cereals.
  • Oral supplements are available in various formulations, from simple salts to complex compounds.
  • Usually, up to 200 mg of elemental iron per day is prescribed, divided into 3-4 doses.
  • Iron is best absorbed on an empty stomach, although gastric conditions or prior surgeries may reduce absorption.
  • Approximately 50 mg/day is absorbed from this dose, enough to triple red cell production under erythropoietin stimulation.
  • Therapy should continue for 6-12 months to restore iron stores (at least 0.5-1 g), beyond just correcting anemia.
  • However, gastrointestinal side effects (like nausea, pain, vomiting, and constipation) occur in some patients and can reduce compliance. Modified-release or lower-dose options may help alleviate this.
  • Reticulocyte counts usually rise within 4 - 7 days of starting therapy and peak in about 1 - 1.5 weeks. If no improvement is observed, causes like poor absorption, noncompliance, or other diagnoses should be considered.
  • To test absorption, an iron tolerance test may be performed: two tablets are given on an empty stomach, and serum iron levels are monitored for a rise of at least 100 µg/dL over 2-3 hours. If iron deficiency persists despite oral therapy, parenteral iron may be necessary.

questions.text: Aplastic anemia is caused by all except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Kostmann syndrome causes congenital neutropenia, due to mutations in the genes encoding the granulocyte colony-stimulating factor receptor and neutrophil elastase and may evolve into AML.

All the remaining options can cause aplastic anemia.

questions.text: JAK 2 mutation is seen in all except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

JAK2 mutation is not seen in chronic neutrophilic leukemia among the given options:

  • JAK2 mutation enriched myeloproliferative neoplasms include: Polycythemia vera, primary myelofibrosis, and essential thrombocythemia.(Options A, C, and D ruled out)
  • JAK2, a tyrosine kinase, is essential for the function of the erythropoietin and thrombopoietin receptors and is also utilized by the granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) receptor.
  • Chronic neutrophilic leukemia (CNL) is a clonal proliferation of mature neutrophils with few or no circulating immature granulocytes.
  • CNL was described to be associated with activating mutations of the CSF3R gene encoding the receptor for G-CSF, also known as colony-stimulating factor 3 (CSF3).

questions.text: Rai stage III/IV in CLL staging is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rai stage III/IV in CLL staging among the given options is lymphocytosis along with anemia.

Rai and Binet classification used in CLL is given below.

questions.text: IGHV (Immunoglobulin heavy chain) mutation in CLL is indicative of?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Immunoglobulin heavy chains (IGHV) undergo somatic hypermutation, and ~60% of patients with CLL have IGHV that is ≥2% mutated from germline.
  • This may indicate a more mature, postgerminal center progenitor, and is typically associated with a more indolent(silent/safe) disease course.
  • Conversely, ~40% of patients will have IGHV <2% mutated from germline, which is associated with more rapid progression of disease and short survival prior to the era of therapeutics that target BCR.

questions.text: The second most common cause of death by cancer in females is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The second most common cause of death by cancer in females is breast cancer.

questions.text: Which among the following is a criteria for initiation of CLL treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Among the given options, functional extranodal involvement is a criteria for initiation of therapy in CLL.

questions.text: Cairo bishop criteria include all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cairo Bishop criteria for the diagnosis of tumor lysis Syndrome (TLS) includes hyperphosphatemia, hyperkalemia, hyperuricemia, and hypocalcemia.

  • Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) arises from massive lysis of tumor cells, typically after chemotherapy in rapidly proliferating cancers such as Burkitt's lymphoma, acute lymphoblastic leukemia, and some chronic leukemias.
  • The destruction of tumor cells leads to release of intracellular contents into the bloodstream, causing hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia. (Options B, C, and D ruled out)
  • These disturbances can precipitate acute renal failure due to uric acid and calcium phosphate precipitation in renal tubules.
  • TLS may also occur spontaneously or after treatments like monoclonal antibodies and steroids.
  • Laboratory indicators of high TLS risk include elevated uric acid and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH >1500 U/L).
  • Prevention involves hydration and agents like allopurinol or febuxostat to lower uric acid levels.
  • Rasburicase, a recombinant urate oxidase, is especially effective but contraindicated in G6PD deficiency.
  • In some cases, renal replacement therapy, particularly hemodialysis, is needed.
  • TLS may lead to complications such as cardiac arrhythmias, tetany, or seizures, requiring vigilant monitoring.

Reference:

https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Cairo-Bishop-classification-of-tumor-lysis-syndrome-in-adults_tbl1_230645601

questions.text: The genes which determine ABO blood groups are located on which chromosome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The genes which determine ABO blood groups are located on chromosome 9.

  • Red blood cells and other blood components such as platelets and neutrophils express alloantigens, which can lead to alloimmunization and antibody formation following transfusion.
  • These antibodies may be directed against red cell antigens (RBC), HLA, platelet antigens (HPA), or neutrophil antigens (HNA), and may result in complications like hemolysis, febrile reactions, or TRALI (transfusion-related acute lung injury).
  • Anti-RBC antibodies can belong to IgM or IgG Some IgG antibodies can cross the placenta and lead to hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn.
  • Red cell antigens, also called erythrocyte blood group antigens, are genetically inherited and located on the surface of RBCs. Over 380 such antigens are known, grouped into about 43 systems.
  • These include carbohydrate-based and protein-based groups. Antigens from the ABO system, I, Lewis, and H are carbohydrate-based, while others like Rh, Kell, Duffy, Kidd, and MNS are protein-based.
  • ABO antigens (A and B) are encoded by different alleles, with O being an inactive form. The H allele encodes the H substrate, the absence of which leads to the Bombay phenotype.
  • The Rh system, comprising nearly 56 antigens coded by genes on chromosome 1. The D antigen defines Rh positivity, while its absence indicates Rh negativity.
  • The Kell blood group includes 36 antigens coded by genes present on chromosome 7. K antigen is tested routinely and most people are K-negative. Kx protein, encoded by a gene on the X chromosome, is linked to Kell and its absence results in McLeod phenotype, characterized by RBC abnormalities and muscle and neurologic issues.
  • The Duffy blood group includes antigens like Fya and Fyb and function as receptors for Plasmodium vivax. The Duffy negative phenotype is common in Africans and provides resistance to Plasmodium vivax.
  • Other blood group systems include the Kidd system with antigens coded by genes located on chromosome 18 and MNS system with 49 antigens coded by genes on chromosome 4.

questions.text: Which blood group is more prone to Helicobacter pylori infections?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Blood group O is more prone to Helicobacter pylori infections.

  • Erythrocyte blood groups are defined by specific antigenic molecules present on the surface of red blood cells and other cells. These antigens are inherited and recognized by corresponding antibodies.
  • Their variability has clinical significance in transfusion, pregnancy, and transplantation due to the risk of immune reactions.
  • The diversity of blood group antigens also relates to environmental and pathogen interactions, influencing disease susceptibility. For instance, individuals with blood group O are more prone to Helicobacter pylori infection.
  • Malaria tends to be less severe in individuals with blood group O compared to those with non-O blood groups.

questions.text: Whole blood is stored at which temperature to maintain erythrocyte viability?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Whole blood is stored at 4° C to maintain erythrocyte viability.

  • Whole blood typically has a volume between 250 -300 mL, including additive solution, with plasma content not exceeding 40-50 mL.
  • Hemoglobin levels range from 12-20 g/dL, hematocrit is between 50-70%, and hemolysis should be ≤0.8% at the time of issue.
  • Whole blood is stored at 4±2°C. The duration depends on the additive solution used, usually ranging from 25 - 42 days.(Options B, C, and D ruled out)
  • Citrate dextrose phosphate adenine-1 (CDPA-1) serves as a blood preservative, extending storage duration up to 35 days by enhancing ATP production during storage.
  • This prolongs the viability of stored blood. However, a drawback of CDPA-1 is its potential to promote uric acid stone formation.
  • In comparison, blood stored with other preservatives Citrate-Phosphate Dextrose has a shelf life of 21 days.
  • If the blood undergoes irradiation, storage is limited to 24 hours.

Reference:

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32187700/

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/6710583/

questions.text: Which of the following is the most efficient antigen presenting cell?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most efficient antigen presenting cell is the dendritic cell.

  • Dendritic cells, also known as interdigitating dendritic cells, serve as the principal antigen-presenting cells responsible for initiating T-cell responses to protein antigens.
  • They are primarily located within epithelial tissues and the interstitium and possess a variety of receptors such as toll-like receptors (TLRs) and lectins that help them detect and respond to microbes and other antigens.
  • These cells also exhibit elevated levels of major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules, which are critical for presenting antigens and activating T cells. (Option A ruled out)
  • Upon encountering microbes, dendritic cells migrate to T-cell areas of lymphoid tissues, where they display antigens to T cells using MHC molecules.
  • There are other cells with a dendritic shape found in the germinal centers of lymphoid follicles in organs like the spleen and lymph nodes which are known as follicular dendritic cells.
  • These cells have receptors for the Fc region of IgG and for the complement component C3b.
  • In the epidermis, the immature form of dendritic cells is referred to as Langerhans cells.

questions.text: Cytogenetic abnormalities seen in myelodysplastic syndromes include all except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cytogenetic abnormalities seen in myelodysplastic syndromes include deletion 5, deletion 7, deletion 20, and trisomy 8.

  • Myelodysplastic syndromes encompasses a varied group of hematological conditions marked by bone marrow failure resulting in cytopenias and a heightened risk of transformation to acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
  • Ineffective blood cell production leads to anemia, often with low platelet and neutrophil counts.
  • Abnormal bone marrow features and chromosomal mutations are common. Low-risk MDS is dominated by marrow failure, while high-risk types involve abnormal chromosomes and myeloblasts, with potential for leukemic transformation.
  • MDS is more fatal due to complications from cytopenias or progression to leukemia, although many patients die from comorbid conditions.
  • MDS typically affects the elderly (mean age >70), with a slight male bias. t's uncommon in children, where it often has a genetic basis. Therapy-related MDS, usually caused by chemotherapy or radiation, is not age-related.
  • MDS arises from environmental exposures (e.g., radiation, benzene) or as a delayed consequence of cancer treatments like alkylating agents and DNA topoisomerase inhibitors.
  • Some hereditary conditions such as Fanconi anemia, GATA2, RUNX1 mutations may evolve into MDS.
  • MDS originates from clonal hematopoietic stem cell disorders marked by disrupted cell growth and maturation. Genetic changes are prevalent in both AML and MDS, including chromosomal losses such as deletion 5,7,20, trisomy 8, and mutations in genes like SF3B1, TP53, EZH2, and ASXL1. (Options A, B, and D ruled out)
  • These genetic changes influence prognosis and treatment response. Mutated clones evolve over time, and deep sequencing shows successive mutational events as MDS progresses to AML.

questions.text: All are criteria for accelerated blast phase except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Accelerated blast phase in CML is characterized by <100 × 10 raised to 9/L unrelated to therapy.

  • CML is a clonal myeloproliferative neoplasm arising from hematopoietic stem cells. Its hallmark is the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene, which encodes an active tyrosine kinase.
  • This genetic event results from a reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22, forming the Philadelphia (Ph) chromosome.
  • Without treatment, CML progresses in two or three phases: a chronic phase, an accelerated phase, and a terminal blastic phase.
  • Most patients (90%) are in the chronic phase at diagnosis, often asymptomatic. When symptoms occur, they reflect anemia or splenic enlargement such as fatigue, malaise, early satiety, left upper quadrant discomfort, or weight loss. Thrombotic complications from leukocytosis or thrombocytosis may also arise, with effects like visual disturbances, priapism, or stroke.
  • Splenomegaly is the most frequent finding (20-70%), followed by hepatomegaly, lymphadenopathy, or skin lesions (suggesting transformation).
  • CML can transform into accelerated or blastic phases. Features of accelerated phase include ≥15% blasts in blood, ≥30% blasts and promyelocytes combined, ≥20% basophils, new cytogenetic abnormalities beyond Philadelphia chromosome (cytogenetic clonal evaluation), or platelet counts <100 × 109/L unrelated to therapy. (Options A, B, and C ruled out)

questions.text: The tyrosine Kinase Inhibitor active against T315I mutation in chronic myeloid leukemia is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ponatinib is the only available BCR-ABL1 tyrosine kinase inhibitor active against T315I mutation.

  • Ponatinib is a third generation tyrosine kinase inhibitor effective against both wild-type and mutant forms of BCR/ABL1, and it is uniquely active against the T315I mutation, which is resistant to the other four ATP-competitive TKIs.
  • It is approved for patients who have not responded to at least two other TKIs.
  • In addition to targeting BCR-ABL1, Ponatinib also blocks vascular endothelial growth factor receptor (VEGFR), which likely contributes to the common occurrence of hypertension with its use.
  • Other reported adverse effects include pancreatitis, skin rashes, and arterio-occlusive disease.

Explanations of other options:

Nilotinib (Option A): Nilotinib is a second-generation tyrosine kinase inhibitor approved for use in all phases of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) except the blastic phase. It is associated with toxicities such as hyperglycemia, hyperbilirubinemia, pancreatitis, and cardiovascular complications. Nilotinib is also preferred in cases with specific mutations such as V299L, T315A, and F317L/F/I/C.

Bosutinib (Option C): Bosutinib is a second-generation tyrosine kinase inhibitor approved for all phases of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). It is generally well tolerated, with a relatively low incidence of cardiovascular events compared to other TKIs, but notable side effects include diarrhea, liver enzyme elevations, and renal dysfunction. Bosutinib is also preferred in patients with certain BCR-ABL1 mutations such as Y253H, E255K/V, and F359V/C/I.

Dasatinib (Option D): Dasatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor approved for all phases of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). It is associated with side effects such as myelosuppression, pleural and pericardial effusions, and pulmonary hypertension, particularly at higher doses. Dasatinib is preferred in patients with BCR-ABL1 mutations like Y253H, E255K/V, and F359V/C/I.

choices.text: Inj Cytarabine (100-200mg/m2) + Inj Daunorubicin (60-90 mg/m2) [7+3 regimen]
Inj Cytarabine (100-200mg/m2) + Inj Daunorubicin (60-90 mg/m2) [3+7 regimen]
Inj Cytarabine (100-200mg/m2) + Inj Daunorubicin (45 mg/m2) [7+3 regimen]
Inj Cytarabine (100-200mg/m2) + Inj Daunorubicin (45 mg/m2) [3+7 regimen]

questions.text: Treatment of choice in young patients with AML is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Treatment of choice in young patients with AML is Inj Cytarabine (100-200mg/m2) + Inj Daunorubicin (60-90 mg/m2) [7+3 regimen]

  • The treatment for acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is divided into two phases: induction and postremission management (consolidation).
  • The initial goal is to induce complete remission. The regimen most commonly used in younger patients is: Cytarabine (S-phase specific antimetabolite) at standard dose (100-200 mg/m2) administered as a continuous intravenous infusion for 7 days.
  • Along with it anthracycline therapy(DNA intercalator), which generally consists of daunorubicin (60-90 mg/m2) or idarubicin (12 mg/m2) intravenously on days 1, 2, and 3 (the 7 and 3 regimen).
  • With the 7 and 3 regimen, it has been established that 45 mg/m2dosing of daunorubicin results in inferior outcomes.
  • Older patients, especially those >65 years or with adverse risk disease, or those who are unfit for intensive anthracycline + cytarabine regimens, may be considered for investigational therapyalone or in combination with lower intensity chemotherapy (azacitidine, decitabine, cytarabine), or lower intensity chemotherapy in combination with venetoclax.

questions.text: Hemoglobinopathies are usually?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Almost all hemoglobinopathies are autosomal recessive or autosomal co-dominant.

  • Most hemoglobin disorders are inherited in an autosomal recessive or co-dominant manner, with family history of anemia being a common feature among affected individuals, especially in hemoglobinopathies and thalassemias.
  • Clinical signs often include pallor, jaundice, and splenomegaly. In sickle cell disease, recurrent painful vaso-occlusive crises serve as a key diagnostic clue.
  • Diagnostic evaluation typically begins with a complete blood count, including a reticulocyte count and peripheral smear examination.
  • A persistently elevated reticulocyte count points to hemolytic anemia. Hemoglobin variant identification through techniques like high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) or capillary electrophoresis, particularly when combined with analysis of relatives, can confirm the specific hemoglobin abnormality.
  • Definitive diagnosis can also be made through globin gene DNA sequencing, which is widely available and essential for genetic counseling.
